summary: This document appears to be a background summary and operational strategy memo for law enforcement regarding Jeffrey Epstein. It outlines the history of investigations into Epstein from 2005 onward, details his criminal conduct involving dozens of minor victims in New York and Florida, and describes a planned strategy for his arrest upon his return to the U.S. from France.

persons.name: Jeffrey Edward Epstein
persons.context: The primary subject of the investigation. The document details his history of sexual abuse of minors, his 2008 plea deal, his residences, and the plan for his arrest.

persons.name: Alex Acosta
persons.role: United States Attorney for the Southern District of Florida
persons.context: Met with Epstein's attorneys in 2007, which preceded Epstein's non-prosecution agreement and subsequent state guilty plea.

persons.name: Victim-1
persons.context: A victim who was recruited at age 14 and who subsequently recruited dozens of other minor victims for Epstein in New York City.

persons.name: Victim-2
persons.context: A victim interviewed in Florida who estimated bringing dozens of girls to Epstein.

persons.name: Victim-3
persons.context: A victim interviewed in Florida who reported sexual conduct by Epstein.

connections.description: Epstein victimized Victim-1, who was 14, and she later recruited other minors for him.
Victim-2 was a victim of Epstein's abuse and also recruited other girls for him.
Epstein's attorneys met with Acosta, the U.S. Attorney, which led to the 2007 non-prosecution agreement.
Both were victims of Epstein who were coerced into recruiting other minor girls for him.

events.title: Initial Police and FBI Investigation
events.description: The West Palm Beach Police Department and FBI initiated an investigation after parents reported Epstein abused their daughter from 2002-2005. The investigation included interviews with ~35 victims, a search warrant, and analysis of phone/flight records.

events.title: Meeting with U.S. Attorney Acosta
events.description: Attorneys representing Epstein met with U.S. Attorney Alex Acosta, leading to a non-prosecution agreement.

events.title: Epstein's State Guilty Plea
events.description: Epstein pleaded guilty in Florida state court to soliciting prostitution as part of the 2007 agreement. He was sentenced to 18 months in jail.

events.title: SDNY Opens New Investigation
events.description: The Southern District of New York (SDNY) approached the FBI NY to open a new investigation into Epstein's conduct in New York.

events.title: Planned Arrest at Teterboro Airport
events.description: CEHTTF (likely a law enforcement task force) plans to monitor Epstein's flights and, with CBP assistance, arrest him at Teterboro Airport upon his return from France.

locations: Little St. James, US Virgin Islands
keyFacts: Epstein victimized dozens of minor girls in both New York and Florida, with victims typically aged 14-17. His conduct included various sexual acts, and victims were paid $200-$300 per visit.
Epstein and co-conspirators used intermediaries and coerced victims to recruit other minor girls to maintain a steady stream of victims for sexual acts.

A 2007 meeting between Epstein's attorneys and U.S. Attorney Alex Acosta led to a non-prosecution agreement and Epstein's subsequent 2008 state guilty plea to soliciting prostitution, for which he served ~13 months of an 18-month sentence.
At the time of the document, Epstein was in Paris, France, and law enforcement planned to arrest him at Teterboro Airport upon his return to the U.S. using flight monitoring.
Epstein owned a private jet registered under the LLC 'Plan D' in the Virgin Islands and had high-value residences in Manhattan and Palm Beach targeted for seizure.
